column13: [Ajahn Pasanno](teacher:) reflects on his feelings after Ajahn Chah died.
[Ajahn Pasanno's](teacher:) response to his father's death.

column2: A classic ten-day Thanksgiving Retreat held at the Angela Center before it closed due to fire damage.

column7: Excerpts
Text
Equanimity...your thoughts?
AN 5.57: Five Subjects for Frequent Recollection ([Chanting Book translation](Chanting Book p. 55))
Please explain wise action. How can one see that it is not influenced by craving?

This morning you talked about crossing the floods of obsessive thought by not holding on to or pushing them away. I get that, but it feels like there's something missing – a hole that needs to be filled up with something – a solution?
What should we do during eating? How to eat with meditation?
Learn how to slow down and chew your food well.|The Supreme Patriarch's advice to new monks
Could you please repeat the name of the sutta you mentioned this morning that laid out the ‘whole spiritual path’ in a conversation with the devas?
What is the difference between piti and sukha? Also equanimity and emptiness as a felt sense?
The difference between pīti and sukha.
Path of Purification p. 139: Similes for pīti and sukha.

I volunteer in hospice and was in attendance for the passing of my parents. I notice vast differences in the way people experience their passage. What can we do, while still alive, to prepare for a peaceful and ‘wakeful’ passing? Other than ‘being present,’ is there anything that can be of benefit to others?
AN 5.57: Five Subjects for Frequent Recollection ([Chanting Book translation](Chanting Book p. 55))
Kd [8.26.8](https://suttacentral.net/pli-tv-kd8/en/brahmali?lang=en&layout=plain&reference=main&notes=asterisk&highlight=false&script=latin#26.8.1): Qualities of a good nurse.
Ajahn Chah advises Paul Breiter about the limits of spiritual hospice work.
Would you tell us again the name of the sutta you spoke of last night and in today's Dhamma talk?
What is the best approach to deal with guilt?
MN 22.58: "Whatever is not yours, abandon it."
For those of us who need to routinely rest more due to aging, illness, or disability, could you share some suggestions and advice for how to optimize ths time as mediation in a lying down posture?
Ajahn Pasanno develops lying down meditation after breaking his pelvis.
What are the general similarities and differences between the practice of ānāpānasatiand satipaṭṭhāna? Are they the same practice?
MN 118: Ānāpānasati Sutta
Praise for the question and answer session. Every question is important; can you answer them all?
Can you say something about forgiveness practice?
Bhikkhu Manual p. 254: Asking for forgiveness ceremony
[Bhikkhu Saṅghādisesā 12](BuSs 12): The community grows through mutual support and mutual admonition.
What do you recommend for pet owners with aging, sick pets? Do they get to live out their lives or is a merciful end at the hands of a vet OK?

Could you share some suggestions and advice for using the breath-body as an object of meditation? This seems like a skillful way of meditating when the gross physical body is experiencing a lot of pain. Is there any drawback to that?
Can you address dependent origination and causation?
Ud 1.3: "When this is, that is..."
All you really need to know is that it's going to hurt when you hit the bottom.|Ajahn Chah
Can you tell us your story of when you decided to become a monk?
If you want to stay here, you have to stay at least five years.|Ajahn Chah
Is it important in this practice to ask for forgiveness for intentional/non-intentional actions both in this life and in past lives?
Do you have any suggestions for the position of the hands during standing meditation?
As inspiration for the rest of us, would you please talk about some of your milestone insights over your years of practice and what kept you going over the years, especially when you hit roadblocks?
MN 10: Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta

Inclining mind toward happiness, joy, lightness, exhilaration, the good, sometimes feels a bit Polyanna-ish. What about all the wars, refugees, my job, illness, pain, etc. Aren't these also the way things are – unpleasant, dark, and negative?

You spoke of using the body as reference, backdrop for the breath. Always coming back to the body. Doesn't this foster a sense of attachment to the body as mine? And what if the body is not in good shape, ill, and hurting?

I am doing well when sitting or walking – my container of mindfulness is filling. However, it seems to be leaking during every other activity. Walking to the meal, in my room, going to the bathroom, eating. Help! I seem to be defeating my own efforts.
How can we apply the law of cause and effect in daily life? How can we apply this law to such a simple thing to remove suffering?
Would you remind us what ‘the four pairs, the eight kinds of noble beings’ means and perhaps in a nutshell what is the English translation of the meal blessing?

Could you offer a bit of advice on how to deal with the apparent dichotomy between seeing people (including myself) as real & solid (for example when sending them metta), and the doctrine of no-self whereby there is no such imagined solidity at all – just an ever-changing combination of the khandas?
What if a short breath never comes? Am I stuck on the long breath or can I create a short breath and move on? Are the steps to ānāpānasati sequential, and do I observe them, cultivate them, or both?
How does one avoid controlling the breath when observing it?
In addition to being aware of our body, is it acceptable to use visual imagery? For example, seeing oneself standing by the ocean breathing in air created by the waves.
Could you describe the meaning of abide, pervading, and imbued in the phrase ‘I will abide pervading one quarter with a mind imbued with lovingkindness?’
Does the breath body exist as an object of mind? As the Buddha mentions it so specifically, I would be grateful for more clarification on the ‘breath body.’

I notice that the calmer my mind becomes, the more imperceptible my breath is – to the point of feeling a suspension of breathing and at times a complete cessation. This sometimes seems to lead to sleepiness and torpor. How can I bring my mind back to a state of focus without manipulating my breath?

When negative feelings arise, whether they be fear, anxiety, loneliness, etc., how do we investigate them? Does breathing into these feelings and being fully present (without trying to push them away) help to become aware of the true cause of these feelings? Is the cause of these feelings always craving of some kind?
In a Dhamma talk at Abhayagiri, you quoted Luang Por Chah as saying ‘Nibbāna lies on the shores of death.’ Could you say more about this?
Oftentimes we're really not ready to let go until there's absolutely no alternative left.
How are you satisfied and/or dissatisfied with students?
Whatever expectations I have are my expectations.
What are the consequences of breaking a precept?
The root of hiri and otappa.
Some meditators associate ‘peak experiences’ with spiritual progress. What are the benefits and drawbacks of this approach?
Of the four elements, please explain wind element.

‘Luminous is the mind.’ Is the luminous mind conditioned or unconditioned? If unconditioned, then it's Nirvana. If conditioned/impermanent, then Nirvana is beyond the mind? Yet it can be known by the mind?
Did you say the defilements are advantageous? (The questioner misheard ‘adventitious.’)

Do any of you who reside at the monastery vote in local or national elections? I also wonder if you get involved in public discussions on local policies as they pertain to or potentially affect the monastery?
Abhayagiri engages with local people and the Forestry Department to block a timber harvest.
Persistent physical pain. Not chronic, just from sitting. How do I work skillfully with it? Right now the meditations feel swamped with it?
Could you talk about how to manage doubt when it arises?
It's the continuity of mindfulness and clarity that we build up that's going to alleviate the doubt as opposed to any particular clever answer.
Do monks on retreat feel as much pain as we do? Is pain sankharas?
Can you repeat the aspect of sankharas other than mental volitional energy?
Chanting Book p. 13
Is it better to stick to one mode of breath meditation (visualizations, a mantra, etc.) for a while during the course of a 30-45 minute sit rather than jumping around to various modes?
If the list of the five khandas is intended to be linear, why is sense-consciousness the final one?
MN 43.9: "Conjoined not disjoined"
What is the difference between a fetter and a hindrance?
One of the books I have read suggests to practice the last moment of life every night. What would you suggest for practicing marananussati?
AN 10.48 Ten Reflections ([Chanting book translation](Chanting Book p. 57))

There is a mean streak in my family, a tendency to be dishonest and manipulative. I can see how it has been passed down over generations. I have worked hard to overcome these habits in myself. At this stage of life my familiar relationships are mostly positive and harmonious, but I still sometimes run across their manipulation or dishonesty. I would like to discuss or address it within my family, but there is no apperent recouse or means of addressing the situation. Any suggestions?
I don't teach my family anything.
Ajahn Pasanno's mother visits Abhayagiri.
Sitting with the Sangha, I am learning how to feel joy.
Please say more about what a monastic retreat offers compared to an ‘ordinary’ retreat. What are the differences?
If mind and consciousness are impermanent, what/who is aware? Also, who/what is it that experiences the results of karma, especially after the body dies and perhaps is reborn?

Can you please explain mindfulness or awareness of consciousness? I can understand consciousness arising as a result of stimuli entering the sense doors, but how does one become aware of consciousness itself? Or is this the right question about consciousness?

Last night you spoke about balancing tranquility of mind with investigation or a theme for contemplation. Can you clarify how this can be accomplished without getting into the usual mind states of planning, associating, etc.?
Mistaken assumption: "I think, therefore I suffer. If I didn't think, then I wouldn't suffer."
Path of Purification p. 104: Forty subjects of meditation.
Can you say something about the difference between ‘the mind’ and the brain?
Is there a distinction between observing the mind and observing what arises?

It seems that nimittas can appear before the mind is fully settled in concentration. Is it useful to understand what that is happening? Should one ignore the nimitta until concentration is firmly established? Or is there some other response or skillful way to work with the nimitta while establishing samadhi?
Please explain more how did the Buddha cross the flood, by neither going forward nor standing still. What does this mean?
SN 1.1
How could you accomplish studying Buddhism in Thailand with Luang Por Chah? How did Luang Por Chah teach you as a you were a foreigner new monk? How did you cope with the language issue?
It's just like teaching buffaloes.|Ajahn Chah
Dhamma is not about the words, about the concepts, about the ideas. It's about the experience.|Ajahn Chah
You often talk about gladdening and lightening the mind. How do I do that?
Could you speak a little about the structure of the Pali Canon? How much was written down in the Buddha's time?
Could you talk about woman’s ordination (nuns) during the Buddha's time and in modern times?
Could you talk about the role memory plays in perception?

I'm concerned about Alzheimer's disease and getting stuck between life and death, loosing all I've learned about mindfulness practice and all my dignity. Where is the silver lining in this life's challenge?

Please explain the hierarchy of devas, gods, etc. in relation to the Buddha. How is it that a mortal being can be more evolved or enlightened than gods? Do gods and devas create karma? Are they born again as gods or devas or humans?

If a lay person wants to follow the seventh precept in daily life, refraining from entertainment seems fairly straightforward. Would you please explain more specifically refraining from ‘beautification and adornment?’ Does owning artwork fall anywhere into precept seven?
Appreciation for becoming aware of consciousness as a nutriment.
Please demonstrate how to bow. Are there any cultural differences?
Ajahn Chah corrects a candidate's bowing posture at his ordination ceremony.

As I've been pondering about consciousness as nutriment, which pointed me to the self. I am wondering, is the self attachment? But attachment is not permanent either. So could we say the self can be either attachment and/or non-attachment, the owner or non-owner? Not trying to find self, rather understanding self? Perhaps pure self as opposed to impure self? Please comment.

I was a little confused this morning about the nutriments. I'm assuming the nutriments nourish our suffering. What are the nutriments? How would consciousness and mental volition differ in feeding dukkha?
Would you share one of Pooh's many nuggets of wisdom to inspire?

Can you clarify the difference between desire and intention? It seems that either could lead to suffering due to attachments to the results. Yet we are encouraged to have intentions for well-being, health, happiness, etc. Isn't our intention also a desire?
SN 22.22: Dhammacakkappavattanasutta ([Chanting Book translation](Chanting Book V2 p. 2))

In working with the Four Noble Truths, to understand suffering, does the Buddha mean knowing for instance the pain in your heart, the stress around your eyes, or does he also mean to see with insight its karmic effect on yourself and others?
To abandon the cause, does it mean in that moment or completely?
All the stories you told us this morning made me realize the fact that what we are seeking is just right here in our mind. What do you think?
Could you talk more about the two levels of understanding the true nature of karma: mundane and transcendent?
Outside of cause, beyond effect; outside of suffering, beyond happiness.|Ajahn Chah
Competitiveness feels so pervasive here in America. What are your thoughts for working with it or healing it?
The nine bases of conceit.
Could you describe the progression of anagarika and samanera training?
The Middle Way – It is not 50% becoming and 50% annihilation, right? What is it the middle of?

Toward the end of this morning sitting meditation, my body started shaking from left to right for about a minute or so. While this was happening, I was observing it without getting panicked or trying to stop it and then it stopped shaking. How do you explain this experience?

In this afternoon's talk, Ajahn Karunadhammo mentioned the benefits of the bhava that results from practice or the Eightfold Path, but he described a consciousness that doesn't land in or on a self and results in freedom. Is that a consciousness that results in neither arising nor non-arising. Could you elaborate? The moment between in and out breaths seems to hold potential for this kind of consciousness.
You want to pay attention to the experience rather than the idea about it.
DN 11.85, MN 49.25: Consciousness luminous all around.
SN 12.64: Simile of the western wall.
Did the Buddha perform any miracles?
Sutta AN 3.60: The greatest miracle is teaching the Dhamma.
Can the monastics speak about the skillful use of caffeine for their practice?
Can you please explain the asavas?
Please speak a little about kataññu.
Chanting Book p. 33: Verses of Sharing and Aspiration
Ajahn Liem gives Abhayagiri a handwritten essay about gratitude.
English translation: Gratitude p. 9.
How can I continue to deepen my practice in the absence of a living teacher?
Is it useful to investigate how we can only experience one conscious moment at a time?
I was just reading a talk of Ajahn Chah's. He mentions ‘vipassanu.’ Could you explain this more?
An Ajahn visiting Abhayagiri spoke of you receiving an honor. Would you elaborate on what it was, who bestows it, and what it means for you and the community?
Could you talk a bit about the kilesas? How to see them clearly and work with them skillfully without falling into discouragement and self-judgment?
Can you repeat the Thai words for ‘Is it worth it?’ that you mentioned this morning? I'd like to use it as a mantra.
Are there any suttas in the Majjhima Nikaya that you recommend that lay people study?

Can you give me some ideas for antidotes to restlessness? So far the best I have is to give myself a set time and not move one iota from sitting or standing. Another is not to fight it but use it for imaginative contemplation.
It's the continuity of wholesome mental states that allows the mind to become settled and steady.
Why is the Buddha referred to in the present tense in the chants? Is it because we are referring to the present potential within us?
When bowing three times, do you say something in your mind like taking refuge or anything else?

Can you say more about trusting the seeds of meditation practice after Alzheimer's/dementia kick in? What do you mean by going beyond liberation or consciousness? What do you mean by ‘many deeper layers’ are affected by the practice and the fruits of it will express naturally?
A monk with psychic abilities investigates Ajahn Chah's mind after Ajahn Chah loses his mental faculties.
Ajahn Pasanno brings the Wat Pah Nanachat community to Ajahn Chah's nursing kuti to chant verses including Dependent Origination.
The fruits of practice arise through the simple quality of being the one who knows, taking the Buddha as refuge.
After forty years of meditating, what do you still find that is interesting?
Practicing Dhamma...sometimes it's difficult, but it's always interesting.
I am so grateful for the peace I am developing here and in my life. It feels like a refuge. Is it the fourth refuge?
That farang Buddha is really like a farang. He's really tense and stressed.|Ajahn Chah

Several months ago, I started to use the phrase: ‘I'd rather be loved than right.’ This small shift has had a tremendous impact in my life as I relinquish my need to be right, to control and to assert my ego into things.
How important is chanting for one's practice? Do you have any tips for how to recite/remember the Pali chants?
Ajahn Mun would chant for over an hour each evening before he started meditating.
AN 10.60 Girimānanda Sutta; SNSN 22.22: Dhammacakkappavattanasutta ([Chanting Book translation](Chanting Book V2 p. 2)).
The evening program at Wat Fah Krahm is three hours of chanting followed by a three-hour sit.
Chanting Book p. 138: Rhythm of the Pāli language.
SN 48.9: Mindfulness related to memory.

I'm having a hard time with alcohol (not here!). Not heavy or even daily use; a glass of wine with dinner a few nights a week or at social events. I would like to stop but have a hard time sustaining for more than a month or so. Any words of encouragement?
When you spent time with family, did you notice any old habits resurfacing?
Can you please speak about faith? How to develop it? How to maintain it through the ups and downs of practice? How have you maintained your faith over forty years of practice?

I was wondering if the merit we have done for meditation practice can be dedicated to the people (dead or alive) we pray for? How do we know it? Also, I have heard that the merit from practicing meditation will accumulate and stay with ones who have practiced that, which also carries over throughout the life or the subsequent incarnations. Can you clarify this?
told by Ajahn Paññānanda about dedication of merit.

I understand that there is a council of Theravada elders who are a ‘decision making panel’ guiding the tradition. Who exactly is part of this council and who or what determines their eligibility? Will the honor being bestowed upon you and Ajahn Amaro next month make you eligible? Are there other monks in modern times who have received this honor?

If I remember correctly, you said with practice what can be realized is not so much the abandonment of the self but the misperception of a self given there has never been a self to be abandoned, correct?
MN 72.15: I-making and my-making (aṅkārama-maṅkāra).
Can you give a concrete description of how you recollect or contemplate? What's going on in your mind while you do it? What resources or mental formations do you use?
The most effective contemplation takes place when the mind is still.
What chants would you recommend as suitable to use for patients who may be in hospice or close to death? Can Buddhist monks give last rites?
Ajahn Chah requests an army truck to pick up Por Puang's body.
Stillness Flowing p. 662.

The Buddha said that vedana is either pleasant, unpleasant, or neither. Contemplating papañca, I noticed that it felt comfortable – familiar and unthreatening. Would a better way to ‘neither pleasant nor unpleasant’ be ‘comfortable’ rather than ‘neutral?’
Can you tell us what you find interesting about the breath? What insights have arisen for you from watching the breath?

Do you have any tips for embodying the Dhamma in business situations when negotiating with aggressive individuals? I tend to walk away at a certain point, but am wondering if there's another way to turn it around, make it better for everyone?
Have you ever put a publication together on the retreat questions? Are the talks of this retreat being recorded?
[Abundant, Exalted, Immeasurable]() transcribes the talks and questions from the [2008 Metta Retreat](event:Metta2008).

For decades, I believed the suffering was the food itself–that cake, that pastry, more food, another bowlful. But now I understand dukkha is not ‘the thing.’ It is the overwhelming craving, the feeling itself. And now that the dukkha is understood, how do I tolerate that feeling?
Is it possible to meditate on forgiveness for someone who died many years ago? Does forgiveness reach that person on some level, or is it more a matter of showing compssion towards myself?
Could you explain what your ordination names mean and how they were chosen?
How does the process work to get a title as you do? Is this title only for monks? Will you be the only one in the USA?

I understand that our genetic disposition can't be changed, but epigenetics say that their expression can be modified by changing lifestyle. In a similar way, our kamma is given but your teachings say the expression and effects can be changed by practice. Please comment.

I often feel overwhelmed with the greed, hatred, ill-will, and delusion that the corporate world exerts over the masses to the benefit of only themselves and that is destroying the planet's ability to renew itself. Could you speak about Buddhist involvement in social change movements?
[Ajahn Pasanno](teacher:) reflects on the results of his efforts to preserve forests in Thailand.
Can I set an example myself and can I help encourage other people who are interested?
Who are the most senior monks in the Theravāda/Thai Forest Tradition? Can you speak about the lineage? Are there Thai teachers of your seniority who come to the West?
Sometimes people assume that the Thai Theravāda Forest Tradition is one thing. – No.
There's nothing organized about this religion.|Ajahn Siripañño
What is the pill in the little vial that sits next to you?
I have attended many deaths and that last breath appears to be really difficult to relinquish. Does this training really help? I have trouble relinquishing the small aches and pains in my body.
The holding on is way more painful than the relinquishing.
In the Ānāpānasati Sutta, what is meant by ‘breathing in/out tranquilizing the mental formation?’
Can you recommend a reflection or phrase to use immediately upon awakening in the morning or the last thing before sleep?
I'm curious about the ceremony to bestow the honorific title. What does it entail? What is the new title? Does it change the appropriate way for us to address or refer to you?

If one were to choose a life partner who was not practicing the Dhamma as we know it but had some spirited lightness about them, what are some qualities we should look for in them that would make them a good partner?
What did you plan to say [on this retreat]?
Do you think it's possible to experience Nibbāna before becoming fully awakened - ‘moments of enlightenment?’ But if Nibbāna is beyond consciousness, would you remember that it happened?
Is there a way to measure concentration, mindfulness, and awareness?
